Bridalveil Falls.name: Bridalveil Falls
reviews: We were lucky when traveling through Yosemite in February. The weather was in the 60's and sunny. We stopped and took the short hike to the falls. It is well worth it. Beautiful view from the viewing area. Highly recommended!

This is a great little walk for smaller children or those that cant do the longer, steeper hikes. The waterfall is beautiful! We were lucky enough to be there when the spray had frozen to the surrounding rocks to make gorgeous ice falls...
We visited in June of 2017, when the waterfalls were full and active. Bridalveil fall had a double rainbow and made for amazing photos that looked like it was a backdrop not a real location.

Bridalveil Fall is one of the most prominent waterfalls in the Yosemite Valley in California, seen yearly by millions of visitors to Yosemite National Park.[1] The waterfall is 188 metres (617 ft) in height and flows year round.[2]

The Ahwahneechee tribe believed that Bridalveil Fall was home to a vengeful spirit named Pohono who guarded the entrance to the valley and that those leaving the valley must not look directly into the waterfall lest they be cursed. They also believed that inhaling the mist of Bridalveil Fall would improve one's chances of marriage.

There was parking available if you chose to drive your car to the Falls, but since we were staying at Yosemite Valley Lodge, we used the shuttles to get around whenever possible to avoid the traffic and parking hassles. We wore waterproof hiking shoes and had no problem getting to the waterfall, but many people had to walk barefoot or simply turn around. Watch out for flood warning.

Outstanding waterfall and white capped rivers. This was the most amazing spectacle of scenic beauty I had seen in years. It was great to take videos of the rushing waters. This has been the best year to visit Yosemite in years thanks to the heavy rains and the end of the drought. Transit from the park boundary is not the best. We were misled by locals who directed us to a YARTS stop that was only served by request. We called to request service but we're unable to get through to either a live person or an automated stop request. We ended up waiting for hours to get into the park and access attractions. The National Park service really needs to add large parking lots 2 miles in advance of the park entrances with convenient and logical access to YARTS to incentivize transit use and significantly reduce private automobile traffic into the park. We also need passenger rail between the Fresno and Merced Amtrak Stations and the YARTS facilities near the park entrances.
